body_html:
I think you can just write the python code and get the same performance in this case, without having to write new C++ kernels, which add to the complexity, maintenance cost, and binary size of tensorflow.
…
On Thu, Jul 26, 2018 at 7:50 PM Ethan Brooks ***@***.***> wrote: Wait, @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> there are lots of tensorflow ops that can be implemented in terms of existing ops (e.g. expand_dims). But implementing repeat is a hassle, prone to errors, and not easily readable. Please clarify why this merge request is getting rejected? — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <#18350 (comment)>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAATxR3y0hXcKo_77csZnhYkyTCKVK2zks5uKn_agaJpZM4TM5ar> .
-- - Alex

body:
I think you can just write the python code and get the same performance in
this case, without having to write new C++ kernels, which add to the
complexity, maintenance cost, and binary size of tensorflow.

On Thu, Jul 26, 2018 at 7:50 PM Ethan Brooks <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Wait, @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> there are lots of tensorflow
> ops that can be implemented in terms of existing ops (e.g. expand_dims).
> But implementing repeat is a hassle, prone to errors, and not easily
> readable. Please clarify why this merge request is getting rejected?
>
> —
